body:
I think that comes from the fact that the generic value could match different interfaces we have `assertThat` for, I believe it worked with java 7 as the jdk for java 7 was buggy and allowed this but java 8+ compiler don't anymore.
If I'm right, there is not much we can do except disambiguating `assertThat` methods by renaming some, for ex `assertThatComparable` but that's not something that I'm keen to do.

Todo list for this issue:
- add that explanation to the FAQ.
- add a should_not_report_ambiguous_reference_compilation_error
- move `assertThat(CompletionStage)` from `AssertionsForClassTypes` to `AssertionsForInterfaceTypes`

rename.from: Return values of generic methods cannot be asserted
rename.to: Assertions#assertThat ambiguous reference error when passing a bounded generic instance

rename.from: Assertions#assertThat ambiguous reference error when passing a bounded generic instance
rename.to: Assertions.assertThat ambiguous reference error when passing a bounded generic instance

issue.title: NoSuchMethodError

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary
Upgrading from 3.9.0 to 3.9.1 cause the following error for my tests:

java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.assertj.core.api.Assertions.assertThat(Ljava/lang/Object;)Lorg/assertj/core/api/AbstractObjectAssert;

#### Example

```java
assertThat(actual).as(description).isNotNull();
```

issue.title: CAM-11105: chore(project): move source code level to Java 8

repository.name: camunda-bpm-platform
repository.description: Camunda 7 CE is End of Life (EoL). Please check out Camunda 8 instead (https://github.com/camunda/camunda) or read about Camunda 7 Enterprise End of Life (https://camunda.com/blog/2025/02/camunda-7-enterprise-end-of-life-extension/) â€“ Camunda 7 CE was a flexible framework for workflow and decision automation using BPMN and DMN.

issue.body:
[![CAM-11105](https://badgen.net/badge/JIRA/CAM-11105/0052CC)](https://app.camunda.com/jira/browse/CAM-11105)<!-- PR-BADGE: PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS COMMENT -->

* bump release parent version (where source/target is config)
* adjust dmn engine tests to not assert a generic value
* ignore failing test in spin

body:
I'm running into this issue, using version 3.21.0.  I verified that the cast fixes the problem, along with now creating a silly-looking warning in Eclipse about unnecessary casts. However, the second workaround about adding AssertionsForClassTypes seems odd.  In the comments here, you simply added that qualification, and that's what I tried.  That results in a new compilation error "Cannot infer type argument(s) for <T> extracting(Function<? super ACTUAL,T>)". However, I see that at http://joel-costigliola.github.io/assertj/assertj-core.html#ambiguous-compilation-error you say something slightly different. You ALSO added the cast to the second workaround.  That fixes the compile error on the "assertThat" call, but of course it does, because the cast itself does that.  However, adding both the "AssertionsForClassTypes ." reference AND the cast results in a different compile error, on a later predicate.

My original code line is this:
```
        assertThat(wlsCartNode.at("/losgs/losg16170729/lineItems/128579015349").withArray("payments"))
            .extracting(jn -> jn.at("/paymentTenderReference").asText())
            .doesNotContain(PaymentConstants.PAYMENT_TENDER_COF);
```
This gets the error:
```
The method assertThat(Predicate<Object>) is ambiguous for the type ...
```
If I change it to:
```
		assertThat(((JsonNode)(wlsCartNode.at("/losgs/losg16170729/lineItems/128579015349").withArray("payments"))))
				.extracting(jn -> jn.at("/paymentTenderReference").asText())
				.doesNotContain(PaymentConstants.PAYMENT_TENDER_COF);
```
It compiles without error (and works).

If I instead use the second workaround, as specified at http://joel-costigliola.github.io/assertj/assertj-core.html#ambiguous-compilation-error , not in this issue, as this:
```
        AssertionsForClassTypes.assertThat(((JsonNode)(wlsCartNode.at("/losgs/losg16170729/lineItems/128579015349").withArray("payments"))))
        .extracting(jn -> jn.at("/paymentTenderReference").asText())
        .doesNotContain(PaymentConstants.PAYMENT_TENDER_COF);
```
It gets an error on the last line, saying "The method doesNotContain(String) is undefined for the type AbstractObjectAssert<capture#75-of ?,String>".

I see that if I try to add a new predicate before that one and just enter "doesNot" and let it show me completions, it shows me "doesNotHave(Condition)" and some other related choices.
In this case (note that I didn't write this code), "doesNotContain" is not as apropos as "isNotEqualTo", which does not have this problem.
